content.rendered:
Today we have a food-themed set of Friday Likes and a game of Two Truths and a Lie, with one of these projects from Moscow, Paris, and London, not being real

Mary Wong Noodle Bar by Fork

A new noodle bar, Mary Wong, in the city of Rostov-on-Don in Russia aims to capture the “dizzying nights in Tokyo and New York” through an identity and materials with pitch black backgrounds, concentric lines, and extra colorful splashes of bright color in the shape of minimalist animal silhouettes. Designed by Moscow-based Fork, this project has a wonderful simplicity to it, starting with the 8-letter logo divided into two neat, monospace lines. Even though it shouldn’t, the squarer sans serif of the logo works well with the condensed rounded sans and that definitely has to be the sexiest chopstick wrapper ever. See full project

Le Jardin Colonial by Adrien Grant Smith Bianchi

This will the lamest game of Two Truths and a Lie: This is the lie. There is no way of writing a blurb about it and keeping it a mystery. Designed as a personal project by 21-year-old, Paris-based student, Adrien Grant Smith Bianchi, Le Jardin Colonial brings together the three passions he lists on his profile, “tea, gardens and graphic design”. Imagined as an epicerie selling all kinds of old-timey, old-world-y teas and goods, Adrien has gone where few designers are going today: an ornate, art nouveau-ish, patterned, bordered, natural-looking design aesthetic that feels oddly refreshing in how elaborate and fuzzy it is. Those shopping bags are the kind you would find in your grandma’s closet and you’d think, “Wow, grandma, cool!” and then she’d tell you a whole story about that time she was romanced by an Arab Sheik. Or something. Point is: wonderful imagined project that steps out of today’s minimalist-everything self-initiated projects. See full project here.

Fatties by Dot Dash

Selling things like “cardamon and pistachio caramels, bags of passion fruit sherbet with pineapple lollipops, and coconut flour brownies”, Fatties is a small London bakery with a provocative name. Yet, the logo design, created by local firm Dot Dash, set in a thin, condensed rounded sans serif diffuses the situation with playful variations where one letter gets “fat” not by getting bold but by stretching out wide. It’s an interesting juxtaposition of verbal and visual elements that you will most likely forget the moment you stuff your face with one of their concoctions. While I enjoy the logo, I’m not convinced by the heavily-used texture that is meant to evoke the “floured surfaces seen in bakeries”, it feels harsh in contrast to the logo and color palette. Nonetheless, put this in front of me and I’ll forgive anything. See full project.

excerpt.rendered: Today we have a food-themed set of Friday Likes and a game of Two Truths and a Lie, with one of these projects from Moscow, Paris, and London, not being real…
